hedline.hl1: I Can See the Eye Chart Now, and Even the Letters!

abstract.p: Sarah Lyall article on Lasik treatment that ended her years of dependence on corrective eyeglasses (M)

block.p: Surgery that would let me give up my glasses forever had always sounded too good to be true, like one of those ads promising that you can earn $10,000 a month by sitting around the house doing nothing. I had been discussing it with my eye doctor for years, and for years, the doctor had told me the technology was not yet advanced enough.
But he changed his mind because of improvements in the technology. ''We can do it, if you're ready,'' he said last summer.

Surgery that would let me give up my glasses forever had always sounded too good to be true, like one of those ads promising that you can earn $10,000 a month by sitting around the house doing nothing. I had been discussing it with my eye doctor for years, and for years, the doctor had told me the technology was not yet advanced enough.
But he changed his mind because of improvements in the technology. ''We can do it, if you're ready,'' he said last summer.
I directed my unfiltered gaze to the eye chart on the wall. It was silly to bother. As usual, I couldn't make out any of the letters. In truth, I couldn't even tell that there was an eye chart.
Yes, I told him, I'm ready.

Sure, I had my concerns. I worried that it would smell like burning eyeball, or feel as if someone were taking an X-acto knife to Jell-O. I worried that I would go blind, develop a disfiguring infection or have to spend the rest of my life wearing tinted, oversized double-thick aviator glasses.

There is no question that I was severely nearsighted and a good candidate for Lasik treatment. I'd worn glasses since I was 7 and, according to family legend, failed to see the beautiful wild goat silhouetted against the sunset while we were on vacation in Greece.

Those first glasses -- bulbous tortoise-shell ones that clashed with my Dorothy Hamill haircut -- were followed by other, equally dismaying ones, and then some years later by contact lenses, which tended to become dry, scratchy and unbearable, forcing me back into the glasses.

Meanwhile, my eyesight kept spiraling downward, finally settling at a miserable -8.5. This is roughly equivalent to having 20-1,600 vision, meaning that what a perfectly sighted person could see from 1,600 feet away, I could see at 20 feet. But I wore my disability, which included considerable astigmatism, with perverse pride, happily using it to explain a number of my most glaring personal failures, including a pathological fear of heights, an inability to remember what people looked like, and a tendency to drive in a way that made my passengers want to take the bus.
What would happen, I wondered, when I lost the ability to not see?

It happened last fall, at a laser lab in the gold-encrusted Trump Tower on Fifth Avenue and 57th Street. Fortified with the drugs I'd been prescribed, Valium and Percocet, I took my seat along with a half-dozen other laser patients, all of them men in their mid-30's. They had brought their wives. I brought my mother. We were all dead nervous.

We swapped stories about lifetimes hobbled by corrective lenses, and then it was my turn. I sat down, surrounded by nurses whose job, it seemed, was to prevent me from running from the room. And then the doctor began, one eye after the other.

He gave me some numbing drops. And then he clamped my eyelid open to prevent me from blinking, and put a suction ring around my eye. Then he took the microkeratone -- which looks like a mini-version of a butcher's meat-slicing machine -- and moved it across the eye, cutting a tiny flap in the cornea.

After that, which made everything go dark for about a minute, the actual laser was not that bad. The suction ring was removed, and I could see again. My job was not to flail erratically, not to sob pitiably, and, most frighteningly, not to divert my eye from a light blinking overhead.

''Whatever you do, DON'T LOOK AWAY,'' my doctor said ominously. I did not smell burning, of fresh eyeball or singed flesh or anything else. And I didn't feel any pain, only a lot of discomfort and a strong desire to shout, ''Get your finger out of my eye!''

The doctor flooded my eye with liquid, taking what felt like a mini-paintbrush and stroked my eyeball over and over, to get the flap to re-attach itself over the cornea. And then he did the same thing to the other eye.

It didn't hurt, but by the end, my eyes felt so dry and scratchy that all I wanted to do was close them and crawl away somewhere dark. Which is what I did next, in a dimly lighted communal recovery room along with several patients who had already had the surgery.

The other patients' wives (and my mother) asked anxiously how we felt. We felt as though someone were blowing sand into our eyes with a straw. But when I left the laser lab, wearing a pair of goggles and an enormous pair of surgical sunglasses, I had enough vanity left to make it clear to those who joined us on the Trump Tower elevator that, No, I had not had a face lift, but an important, medically necessary ocular procedure. (My insurance company didn't think it was medically necessary, of course: it cost $5,000, out of pocket).
The next few weeks were strange ones, as my eyes healed and I began to realize that, in fact, I could see again in a way that I had never imagined.

It's a hard feeling to describe, because it's not as if I'd been actually blind before. But I'd always taken my fragile sight to be a precarious commodity, a favor that, having been granted, could easily be snatched away. And then there was the ever-present fear of being caught in a thunderstorm in the middle of the woods, losing my contact lenses, breaking my glasses and starving to death when I could not find my way home.

Now, I've almost forgotten all those years of gray, all those lenses and inchoate worries. My eyes are better than 20-20: I can see the tiny little line of letters at the bottom of the eye chart, the optional ones. And when I wake up, it's just me facing the world without any distorting layers, with eyes that seem sharper and brighter and more alive than they ever have before.
